content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." It provides legal recourse for consumers. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. In successful cases, the prevailing party may also receive costs and attorney fees. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements, along with costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. Increased requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for documentation provided by consumers, enhancing requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for documentation provided by consumers, enhancing requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information, including all relevant documentation in consumer disputes. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require the Bureau to provide reports on consumer disputes to relevant parties at appropriate intervals. The Bureau will also establish rules for gathering information from consumer reporting agencies to generate these reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to follow procedures ensuring accurate consumer reports. The Bureau will issue a proposed rule within a year to establish these procedures. The Bureau will issue a proposed rule to establish procedures for consumer reporting agencies to ensure accurate consumer reports, considering factors like matching consumer information for improved accuracy. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is being amended to include additional information that would aid in ensuring accurate consumer reports furnished by consumer reporting agencies. This includes responsibilities of furnishers of information and disclosures to consumers regarding the permissible purpose of obtaining consumer reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is being amended to include responsibilities for furnishers of information and disclosures to consumers regarding the permissible purpose of obtaining consumer reports, including providing the consumer with a credit score derived from a widely distributed credit scoring model for any extension of credit or transaction designated by the consumer. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse information and free provision of credit scores upon consumer request in connection with an annual consumer report. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse information. Consumer reporting agencies must provide free disclosures within 14 days of receiving a notification under specific sections. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse information. Consumer reporting agencies must provide free disclosures within 14 days of receiving a notification under specific sections, including providing the consumer with a copy of the current credit report and other required disclosures without charge. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse actions. Consumer reporting agencies must provide free disclosures to consumers, including a copy of the consumer report and information on disputing any inaccuracies. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse actions, with a focus on providing consumers with disclosures and the right to dispute any inaccuracies in their consumer report. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse actions, directing consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with disclosures as described in section 612(b). Additionally, the Bureau is required to publish a proposed rule within one year to implement these disclosure requirements. The Bureau must consider what information would help consumers understand reasons for adverse actions or credit offers on less favorable terms, and how to provide this information while protecting consumer privacy. SEC. 4. REGULATORY REFORM. The Bureau will establish 3 publicly available registries of consumer reporting agencies within 180 days of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act enactment. All consumer reporting agencies must register with one of the registries. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems and the feasibility of a national government-administered consumer credit reporting system. Findings will be published within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE: The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment.
